facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 90 of 1953 under Article 132 of the Constitution from High Court judgment dated 29th August 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 90 of 1953. Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 29th August, 1952, of the High Court of Travancore

facts.text: High Court of Travancore-Cochin at Ernakulam dismissed Original Petition No. 51 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 29th August, 1952, of the High Court of TravancoreCochin at Ernakulam in Original Petition No. 51 of 1952.

facts.text: Petitioner entered service of erstwhile Travancore State in 1928.

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to the petition and the appeal are these The petitioner entered the service of the erstwhile Travancore State in the year 1928.

facts.text: Petitioner became Executive Engineer, Electricity Department in August 1937.

anchor.surface_text: By promotion he became the Executive Engineer, Electricity Department in August 1937 and subsequently Electrical Engineer to Government in October 1944.

facts.text: Petitioner became Electrical Engineer to Government in October 1944.

anchor.surface_text: By promotion he became the Executive Engineer, Electricity Department in August 1937 and subsequently Electrical Engineer to Government in October 1944.

facts.text: States of Travancore and Cochin integrated on 1st July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He was the Electrical Engineer to Government on the 1st July 1949 when the States of Travancore and Co- chin were integrated by a Covenant

facts.text: Petitioner appointed officiating Chief Engineer Electricity by order dated 11th August 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of the Government of the united State of Travancore-Cochin dated the 11th August 1949, he was appointed as the officiating Chief Engineer  Electricity  in the State.

facts.text: Government received complaints about conduct of senior officers in September 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In or about September 1949 the Government of the 1014 united State received serious companyplaints about the companyduct and dealings of some of their senior officers

facts.text: Council of Ministers decided to take action against petitioner on charges in December 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1949 the Council of Ministers decided to take action against the appellant on a number of charges indicated in the resolution.

facts.text: Petitioner suspended on 22nd December 1949 and handed over charge to Sri K. P. Sridharan Nair.

anchor.surface_text: On the 22nd December 1949, immediately after this resolution was passed, the petitioner was informed that he was suspended from service pending enquiry and he was requested to hand over charge to Sri K. P. Sridharan Nair forthwith.

facts.text: Notification issued on 21st March 1950 for inquiry under Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act XI of 1122 appointing Sri K. Sankaran as Commissioner and Sri T. R. Balakrishna Ayyar as prosecutor.

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st March 1950 the following numberification was issued- Whereas Government are of opinion that there are sufficient grounds for making a formal and public inquiry into the truth of the imputation of misconduct of the officers mentioned below Government, under section 3 of the Travancore Public Servants  Inquiries  Act, XI of 1122, hereby companymit the said inquiry to Sri K. Sankaran, Judge, High Court, appointed Commissioner for the purpose.

facts.text: Petitioner informed of inquiry by notice on 24th April 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was informed by numberice of the 24th April 1950 about this inquiry.

facts.text: Enquiry commenced on 20th May 1950; petitioner pleaded not guilty.

anchor.surface_text: On the 20th May 1950 when the enquiry companymenced, the petitioner pleaded number guilty to the charges by a written statement.

facts.text: Preliminary objection to tribunal's jurisdiction based on Article 20 of Covenant raised and overruled.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken to the Tribunals jurisdiction on the basis of Article 20 of the Covenant entered into between the rulers of Tra- vancore and Cochin and it was companytended that the proceedings before the Commissioner were criminal in nature and companyld number be companymenced without the sanction of the Rajpramukh and that its absence was fatal to the enquiry.

facts.text: Petitioner submitted detailed answers to charges on 22nd November 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the 22nd November 1950 the peti- tioner submitted detailed answers in writing to the various charges.

facts.text: Enquiry concluded on 27th December 1950; report submitted 17th February 1951; some charges proved, others not.

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry companycluded on the 27th December 1950 and the Commissioner submitted his report to Government on the 17th February 1951. Some of the-charges were held proved, while others were held number established.

facts.text: Show cause notice sent on 5th July 1951 agreeing with findings, dropping some charges, condoning one, proposing removal from suspension date with bar.

anchor.surface_text: On the 5th July 1951 the following companymunication was sent to the petitioner by the Chief Secretary to Government- I am to enclose here with a companyy of the above report and to point out that the Government agree with the findings of the Inquiring Commissioner on the several charges against you.

facts.text: Petitioner granted time extensions to show cause: till 10 Sep, then till 24 Sep 1951; further request denied; failed to show cause.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner on receipt of this numberice applied for time till the 10th September 1951 for showing cause. Time as prayed for was allowed. On the 10th September 1951 when the time granted at his own request 1017 was due to expire, he again applied for further time till the 10th November 1951.

facts.text: Public Services Commission consulted before submission to Rajpramukh and supported proposed action.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that before the papers were submitted to H. H. the Rajpramukh, the report of the Commissioner was submitted to the Public Services Commission for their companysideration. The Public Services Commission supported the action which the Government proposed to take against the petitioner.

facts.text: Removal order dated 1st October 1951 by Rajpramukh; effected 9th October 1951 w.e.f. 26th December 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The order was in proper form as having been made by H. H. the Rajpramukh and was authenticated by the Chief Secretary to Government. This order is dated the 1st October 1951. ... On the 9th October 1951 the petitioner was removed from service with effect from the 26th December 1949.

facts.text: Petitioner's reconsideration application rejected on 25th January 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Two months after the order of his removal, the petitioner submitted an ap- plication for a reconsideration of the order removing him from service. This was rejected by an order dated the 25th January 1952.

facts.text: Original petition filed in High Court on 2nd June 1952 for certiorari to quash orders dated 9 Oct 1951 and 25 Jan 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts and in these circumstances an application was made before the High Court of Travancore-Cocliin at Ernakulam on the 2nd June 1952 praying that the companyrt may be pleased to issue a writ in the nature of certiorari

facts.text: High Court dismissed petition and certified for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived all the companytentions of the petitioner and dismissed the petition. It however certified that the case involved substantial questions of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution and was a fit one for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held petitioner given reasonable opportunity at both stages under Article 311.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the present case the petitioner had reasonable opportunity at both stages to enter upon his defence. He fully availed himself of the first opportunity and though a reasonable opportunity was also given to him at the second stage, he failed to avail himself of it

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected contention that Article 20 of Covenant required Rajpramukh sanction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived this companytention with the following observations Article 20 refers to the institution of civil and criminal proceedings... In our judgment, Article 20 of the Covenant does number apply to proceedings which are number -criminal but merely partake of that character.

facts.text: Public Service Commission consulted and agreed before show cause; no need after as petitioner did not respond.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the Public Service Commission was in fact companysulted in the matter of the action proposed against the petitioner by removing him. The Public Service Commission agreed to the proposed action.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, finding full compliance with Article 311 and natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: After having examined all the arguments of Mr. Thomas, we are of the opinion that all the rules of natural justice were fully observed during the enquiry in this case, and the petitioner had the fullest opportunity to put in his defence

issues.text: Whether the order of removal violated Article 311(1) of the Constitution by being passed by an authority subordinate to the appointing authority?

anchor.surface_text: The question of the validity of an order of removal of a person employed in a civil capacity under the Union or a State falls to be determined on the provisions of Article 311 of the Constitution of India.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner was given a reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed under Article 311(2)?

anchor.surface_text: As regards the question whether the petitioner was given reasonable opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him, the legal position in that respect and the nature of opportunity to be granted was stated by the Privy Council in the case of High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall

issues.text: Whether the show cause notice was expressed in accordance with Article 166 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Thomas argued that the show cause notice was not in accordance with the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution inasmuch as it was not expressed to have been made in the name of the Rajpramukh.

issues.text: Whether principles of natural justice were observed in the enquiry and removal process?

anchor.surface_text: that the denial of this right rendered the order of dismissal illegal and void and that it offended against the principles of natural justice.

issues.text: Whether consultation with the Public Service Commission was required and held under Article 320(3)(c) at all stages including after show cause and on review petition?

anchor.surface_text: consultation with the Public Services Commission was not held in terms of the provisions of procedure for disciplinary action against Government servants and prescribed in Article 320, sub- section 3 c  of the Constitution of India.

issues.text: Whether sanction of the Rajpramukh under Article 20 of the Covenant was required for the departmental inquiry as it was criminal in nature?

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken to the Tribunals jurisdiction on the basis of Article 20 of the Covenant entered into between the rulers of Tra- vancore and Cochin and it was contended that the proceedings before the Commissioner were criminal in nature

issues.text: Whether the order appointing the Enquiry Commissioner and prosecutor under sections 3 and 4 of the Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act was validly made by the Council of Ministers?

anchor.surface_text: under section 3 of the Travancore Public Servants  Inquiries  Act, XI of 1122, hereby commit the said inquiry to Sri K. Sankaran, Judge, High Court, appointed Commissioner for the purpose. Government are further pleased under section 4 of the said Act to nominate Sri T. R. Balakrishna Ayyar, Government Pleader, High Court, to prosecute the inquiries on their behalf.

issues.text: Whether the notification appointing the Enquiry Commissioner was expressed in proper form under Article 166?

arguments.claim: Under Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act only Maharaja could appoint Commissioner, not Council of Ministers; 'Our Government' means Maharaja

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that under the Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1122 it was only the Maharaja who could make an order under the provisions of that Act, and that the Ministers could not take any action. Emphasis was lai on the expression Our Government

court_response_anchor.surface_text: taken against the order of dismissal. The High Court negati

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Our Government' post-integration means Council of Ministers; Rajpramukh acts on ministers' advice

arguments.claim: Article 20 Covenant requires Rajpramukh sanction for proceedings against petitioner (appeal reiteration)

anchor.surface_text: Another point taken by Mr. Thomas was that without the sanction of the Rajpramukh the proceedings could not be started against the petitioner and reliance for this contention was placed on Article 20 of the Covenant

court_response_anchor.surface_text: per form and that the Commissioner did number companyduct the enquiry in accordance with the provisions of the Act. The numberification ordering an en

arguments.court_reasoning: Departmental proceedings not civil or criminal proceedings under Article 20

arguments.claim: PSC consultation required after show cause response and on review petition under Article 320(3)(c)

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was urged that there was no-compliance with the provisions of Article 320, clause 3 c of the Constitution which provides that on all disciplinary matters... the State Public Service Commission... shall be consulted.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n and the formation of the United State of Travancore-Cochin the expression Our Government has to be companystrued according to the new set-up of Gove

arguments.court_reasoning: Consulted before; no response so no need after; multiple consultations on reviews not required

arguments.claim: All requirements of Article 311 satisfied as removal by appointing authority and reasonable opportunities given

anchor.surface_text: The question of the validity of an order of removal of a person employed in a civil capacity under the Union or a State falls to be determined on the provisions of Article 311 of the Constitution of India.

arguments.claim: Article 166 directory; substantial compliance sufficient, citing precedent

anchor.surface_text: It was held by this Court in Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. The State of Bombay that clauses 1 and 2 of Article 166 are directory only and non-compliance with them does not result in the order being invalid,

arguments.claim: Principles of natural justice fully observed; fullest opportunities provided

anchor.surface_text: After having examined all the arguments of Mr. Thomas, we are of the opinion that all the rules of natural justice were fully observed during the enquiry in this case, and the petitioner had the fullest opportunity to put in his defence

arguments.claim: Article 20 of Covenant does not apply to departmental proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived this contention with the following observations Article 20 refers to the institution of civil and criminal proceedings... In our judgment, Article 20 of the Covenant does not apply to proceedings which are not -criminal but merely partake of that character.

holdings.text: The order of removal was made by the Rajpramukh, the appointing authority, satisfying Article 311(1).

anchor.surface_text: There was no occasion to raise this issue because the order of removal had been made by the Rajpramukh and was expressed according to the provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution. The requirement therefore of sub-clause 1 of Article 311 was fully satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order authenticated by Chief Secretary and expressed per Article 166; no evidence of subordinate authority.

holdings.text: Petitioner given reasonable opportunity at both stages under Article 311(2); availed first fully, failed to avail second despite extensions.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the present case the petitioner had reasonable opportunity at both stages to enter upon his defence. He fully availed himself of the first opportunity and though a reasonable opportunity was also given to him at the second stage, he failed to avail himself of it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council in I.M. Lall; opportunity at enquiry and show cause stages; petitioner inspected files, defended fully at first, granted time extensions at second but did not respond.

holdings.text: Show cause notice substantially complies with directory provisions of Article 166.

anchor.surface_text: This was in our opinion substantial compliance with the directory provisions of Article 166 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Signed by Chief Secretary on behalf of Government; cites precedent Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay that clauses (1) and (2) are directory; petitioner accepted and sought extensions.

holdings.text: All rules of natural justice fully observed; petitioner had fullest opportunity to defend.

anchor.surface_text: After having examined all the arguments of Mr. Thomas, we are of the opinion that all the rules of natural justice were fully observed during the enquiry in this case, and the petitioner had the fullest opportunity to put in his defence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facilities for inspection, counsel, cross-examination at enquiry; show cause with report copy and time granted; default by petitioner at second stage.

holdings.text: Consultation with Public Service Commission under Article 320(3)(c) held before show cause and sufficient; no need after non-response or on review.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the Public Service Commission was in fact consulted in the matter of the action proposed against the petitioner by removing him. The Public Service Commission agreed to the proposed action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PSC consulted pre-show cause and approved; no response from petitioner so no further consultation needed; multiple consultations on reviews not required.

holdings.text: Article 20 of Covenant does not apply to departmental proceedings which merely partake of criminal character.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived this contention with the following observations Article 20 refers to the institution of civil and criminal proceedings... In our judgment, Article 20 of the Covenant does not apply to proceedings which are not -criminal but merely partake of that character.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article covers civil/criminal court proceedings only; agrees with High Court; departmental inquiries excluded.

holdings.text: Appointment of Enquiry Commissioner under Travancore Public Servants Inquiries Act validly made by Council of Ministers; 'Our Government' means Council post-integration.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see any force in this contention. The expression Our Government means the Maharajas Government, in other words, the Government of the State of Travancore. After the integration... means The Council of Ministers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-integration, expression adapted to new setup; Rajpramukh acts on Ministers' advice per democratic principle.

holdings.text: Notification appointing Enquiry Commissioner substantially complies with Article 166; presume resolution communicated to Rajpramukh.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Issued post-Ministers' resolution; normal presumption of communication; substantial compliance as directory.

holdings.text: All requirements of Article 311 fully complied with.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that all the requirements of Article 311 have been fully complied with in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative finding on appointing authority and reasonable opportunity.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed; no substantial points to disturb High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, none of the points urged by the learned counsel was of a substantial character and all of them concerned matters of mere form and no valid reasons have been shown for disturbing the decision of the High Court.

precedents.citation: High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall 1

anchor.surface_text: High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall 1 and it was held that when a stage is reached when definite conclusions have been come to as to the charges, and the actual punishment to follow is provisionally determined on, that the statute gives the civil servant an opportunity for which subsection (3) of section 240 of the Government of India Act, 1935 which corresponds to Article 311 makes provision, and that at that stage a reasonable opportunity has to be afforded to the civil servant concerned. It was also held that there was no anomaly in the view that the statute contemplates a reasonable opportunity at more than one stage.

precedents.case_name: High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall
precedents.cited_proposition: Legal position on reasonable opportunity of showing cause against proposed action; opportunity required when conclusions reached on charges and punishment determined; no anomaly in multiple stages of opportunity under corresponding provision to Article 311.
precedents.cited_holding: when a stage is reached when definite conclusions have been come to as to the charges, and the actual punishment to follow is provisionally determined on, that the statute gives the civil servant an opportunity [...] statute contemplates a reasonable opportunity at more than one stage.

precedents.citation: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. The State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. The State of Bombay 1 that clauses (1) and (2) of Article 166 are directory only and non-compliance with them does not result in the order being invalid, and that in order to determine whether there is compliance with these provisions all that is necessary to be seen is whether there has been substantial compliance with those requirements.

precedents.case_name: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. The State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Clauses (1) and (2) of Article 166 are directory; substantial compliance suffices; non-compliance does not invalidate orders.
precedents.cited_holding: clauses (1) and (2) of Article 166 are directory only and non-compliance with them does not result in the order being invalid, and that in order to determine whether there is compliance with these provisions all that is necessary to be seen is whether there has been substantial compliance with those requirements.
